The lanthanide and actinide groups are two different series of elements in the periodic table. The main difference between these two groups is their stability and the way they behave chemically.
The lanthanide series consists of 15 elements with atomic numbers 57 through 71 (lanthanum through dysprosium). These elements are also known as the "rare earth" elements. They are highly reactive and tend to form compounds with a +3 oxidation state. They are also relatively unstable and tend to undergo radioactive decay.
The actinide series consists of 15 elements with atomic numbers 89 through 103 (actinium through lawrencium). These elements are also known as the "actinides." They are much more stable than the lanthanides and tend to form compounds with a +3 or +4 oxidation state. They are also much more radioactive than the lanthanides and undergo radioactive decay more slowly.
In summary, the main difference between the lanthanide and actinide groups is their stability and the way they behave chemically. The lanthanides are highly reactive and unstable, while the actinides are more stable and tend to form compounds with a +3 or +4 oxidation state.

Answer: The most commonly used physical separation process for separating uranium-235 from uranium-238 is gaseous diffusion.
Gaseous diffusion is a process in which uranium is converted into a gas, called uranium hexafluoride (UF6), and then passed through a porous barrier. The UF6 molecules with the higher atomic weight (i.e., uranium-235) will diffuse through the barrier more slowly than the UF6 molecules with the lower atomic weight (i.e., uranium-238), resulting in a separation of the isotopes.
Other separation processes that can be used to enrich uranium include centrifugation and laser separation, but gaseous diffusion is the most commonly used method due to its high efficiency and low cost.
